W1 1. The discipline of social psycholog.title: Week 36 · Introduction to Social Psychology
W1 1. The discipline of social psycholog.description: Thomas Morton opens the Autumn 2025 course with the history, scope, and controversies of social psychology, drawing on Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 1), Doise & Valentim's levels of analysis, Gergen's call to treat the field as history, and the Open Science Collaboration's reproducibility findings.

W2 10. Group behaviour.m4a.title: Week 37 · Connections, Crowds, and the Need to Belong
W2 10. Group behaviour.m4a.description: We explore how other people shape individual psychology through crowd processes, depersonalisation, and bystander dynamics, foregrounding Baumeister & Leary on the need to belong, Hopkins et al. on solidarity in crowds, and Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 10).

W3 9. Social influence.m4a.title: Week 38 · Conformity, Obedience, and Resistance
W3 9. Social influence.m4a.description: Classic studies by Asch, Milgram, and Zimbardo anchor a discussion of group processes, power, and resistance, complemented by Haslam & Reicher's reinterpretation of conformity and Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 9).

W4 2. The social self_ understanding our.title: Week 39 · The Social Self and Intergroup Identity
W4 2. The social self_ understanding our.description: This session examines how dynamic self-concepts emerge from group memberships, featuring Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 2) alongside Tajfel & Turner’s social identity theory and seminar work on Activity 1.

W5 3. The social perceiver_ understandin.title: Week 40 · Making Sense of the Social World
W5 3. The social perceiver_ understandin.description: We look at attribution and social cognition—how people explain behaviour, encode group information, and challenge stereotypes—drawing on Sutton & Douglas (Chs. 3, 11 & 12), Heider’s naïve analysis, Weiner on motivation, and contemporary prejudice research.
